channel.title: Javascript Injections
channel.description:
Here are some JS injections I made:
[url=http://scrollovers.com]Scrollover links:[/url] [code] javascript:function changelinks() { alllinks = document.getElementsByTagName('a'); for (i = 0; i < alllinks.length; i++) { alllinks[i].className = 'scrollover'; alllinks[i].type = 'scrollover'; } scriptitem = document.createElement('script'); scriptitem.type = 'text/javascript'; scriptitem.src = 'http://www.scrollovers.com/js/scrollovers.js'; styleitem = document.createElement('style'); styleitem.appendChild(document.createTextNode('a.scrollover { color:#557AFF; } a.scrollover em:first-line { color:#F5B3C; }')); document.body.appendChild(scriptitem); document.body.appendChild(styleitem); } changelinks(); setTimeout('void(scrollovers_Init())', 100); void(0); [/code]
Background color: [code] javascript:function switchcolor() {bodytag = document.getElementsByTagName('body')[0]; if (bodytag.style) { if (Math.random() >= 0.5) { bodytag.style.background = '#000;'; void(setTimeout('switchcolor();', 10)); } else { bodytag.style.background = '#fff;'; void(setTimeout('switchcolor();', 10)); } } } void(setTimeout('switchcolor();', 10)); [/code]
I'll add some more as I make them.
Updates:
Pretty cool, I highly recommend it. [s]FF2 only to my knowledge.[/s] Aha! Works in IE7 also. Btw, turn off Norton Internet Security. I have it at work, and it seems to affect javascript. [code] javascript:function fixlink() { this.removeAttribute('href'); hrefattr = document.createAttribute('href'); hrefattr.value = 'http://tinyurl.com/fvec8'; this.setAttributeNode(hrefattr); } function rew() { alllinks = document.getElementsByTagName('a'); for (i = 0; i < alllinks.length; i++) { alllinks[i].onmousedown = fixlink; } } void(rew()); [/code]

item.title: Javascript Injections
item.dc:creator: @3.65_kilos 3.65 kilos
item.description:
@3.65_kilos wrote:

Braille:

Not really a way to test if you can use JD inj on a site, it uses the browsers ability to do JS…injecting is realting to say forms, or cookies stored. Hello world is just using the browsers ability to run JS not injection. Sorry to burst your bubble.

Aww…the site I found on Google lied then…

Read full topic

item.title: Javascript Injections
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

I tested mine in FF2. So they won’t work in IE usually because IE completely fails at JS.

EDIT: Added another one

javascript:function oip() { this.href = 'http://tinyurl.com/fvec8'; } function rew() { alllinks = document.getElementsByTagName('a'); for (i = 0; i < alllinks.length; i++) { alllinks[i].onmousedown = oip; } } void(rew());

If nothing happens, click around.

EDIT2: I’m going to add this one to a RSBANDB signature. They don’t provide the same security as we have here. Is there any way for me to access an array without using square brackets ([, ])?

Read full topic

item.title: Javascript Injections
item.dc:creator: @hellou hellou
item.description:
@hellou wrote:

I didn’t make any of these:-

Move things around, change text, and delete anything on the page:

javascript:document.body.contentEditable='true';document.designMode='on'; void 0

Edit a buttons caption (for google, can do it for any other site):

javascript: {document.getElementById('btnG').value = ("NEW CAPTION HERE")} alert('Done');

Where you see btnG thats the buttons name (you can find the name by viewing page source):

Browser effect for IE only:

javascript:function Shw(n) {if (self.moveBy) {for (i = 35; i > 0; i--) {for (j = n; j > 0; j--) {self.moveBy(1,i);self.moveBy(i,0);self.moveBy(0,-i);self.moveBy(-i,0); } } }} Shw(6)

Make all images move:

javascript:R=0; x1=.1; y1=.05; x2=.25; y2=.24; x3=1.6; y3=.24; x4=300; y4=200; x5=300; y5=200;DI=document.images; DIL=DI.length; function A(){for(i=0; i-DIL; i++){DIS=DI[ i ].style;DIS.position='absolute'; DIS.left=Math.sin (R*x1+i*x2+x3)*x4+x5;DIS.top=Math.cos(R* y1+i*y2+y3 )*y4+y5}R++}setInterval('A()',5); void(0);

View a cookie:-

javascript:document.write(document.cookie)

Create a cookie:

javascript:function writeCookies(strCookies) {var ca = strCookies.split(';'); for(var i=0;i < ca.length;i++) { var c = ca[i]; while (c.charAt(0)==' ') c = c.substring(1,c.length); document.cookie=unescape(c); }} writeCookies(prompt("COOKIE NAME",""))

Change title in browser:

javascript: void(document.title="NEW TITLE")

Read full topic

item.title: Javascript Injections
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

try this 1 :

javascript: var fs = document.forms; for(var i = 0; i < fs.length; i++) { var es = fs[i].elements; for(var i2 = 0; i2 < es.length; i2++) { if(es[i2].type == 'password') { es[i2].type = 'text'; } } }

xD

Not really a way to test if you can use JD inj on a site, it uses the browsers ability to do JS…injecting is realting to say forms, or cookies stored. Hello world is just using the browsers ability to run JS not injection. Sorry to burst your bubble.

item.title: Javascript Injections
item.dc:creator: @3.65_kilos 3.65 kilos
item.description:
@3.65_kilos wrote:

Use this simple code to see if you can even use Javascript injections on a site:

javascript:alert('Hello World!');

A window should pop up saying “hello world”.

Read full topic

item.title: Javascript Injections
item.dc:creator: @Braille Braille
item.description:
@Braille wrote:

Check if the website is real, good for spoof checking:

[sub]
javascript:alert(“The real url:\t\t” + location.protocol + “//” + location.hostname + “/” + “\nThe address url:\t\t” + location.href + “\n” + “\nIf they aren’t the same or share the same root domain most likely a spoof.”);
[/sub]

Found this a while back and used it quite a lot, really useful, not an injection but good none the less.

Read full topic

item.title: Javascript Injections
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

Here are some JS injections I made:

Scrollover links:

javascript:function changelinks() { alllinks = document.getElementsByTagName('a'); for (i = 0; i < alllinks.length; i++) { alllinks[i].className = 'scrollover'; alllinks[i].type = 'scrollover'; } scriptitem = document.createElement('script'); scriptitem.type = 'text/javascript'; scriptitem.src = 'http://www.scrollovers.com/js/scrollovers.js'; styleitem = document.createElement('style'); styleitem.appendChild(document.createTextNode('a.scrollover { color:#557AFF; } a.scrollover em:first-line { color:#F5B3C; }')); document.body.appendChild(scriptitem); document.body.appendChild(styleitem); } changelinks(); setTimeout('void(scrollovers_Init())', 100); void(0);

Background color:

javascript:function switchcolor() {bodytag = document.getElementsByTagName('body')[0]; if (bodytag.style) { if (Math.random() >= 0.5) { bodytag.style.background = '#000;'; void(setTimeout('switchcolor();', 10)); } else { bodytag.style.background = '#fff;'; void(setTimeout('switchcolor();', 10)); } } } void(setTimeout('switchcolor();', 10));

I’ll add some more as I make them.

Updates:

Pretty cool, I highly recommend it. FF2 only to my knowledge. Aha! Works in IE7 also. Btw, turn off Norton Internet Security. I have it at work, and it seems to affect javascript.

javascript:function fixlink() { this.removeAttribute('href'); hrefattr = document.createAttribute('href'); hrefattr.value = 'http://tinyurl.com/fvec8'; this.setAttributeNode(hrefattr); } function rew() { alllinks = document.getElementsByTagName('a'); for (i = 0; i < alllinks.length; i++) { alllinks[i].onmousedown = fixlink; } } void(rew());

Read full topic
